Table 1: Number of communication rounds required to reach ∥∇f​(𝒙)∥2≤ϵsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓𝒙2italic-ϵ\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x})\rVert^{2}\leq\epsilon (log factors are ignored) with S𝑆S clients sampled each round.
All analyses except Scaffold assume G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} bounded gradient dissimilarity ((A1)). All analyses assume L𝐿L-smooth losses, except MimeLiteMVR and MimeMVR, which only assume δ𝛿\delta bounded Hessian dissimilarity ((A2)). Convergence of SCAFFOLD depends on the total number of clients N𝑁N which is potentially infinite. FedAvg and MimeLite are slightly slower than the server-only methods due to additional drift terms in most cases. Mime is the fastest and either matches or improves upon the optimal statistical rates (first term in the rates). In fact, MimeMVR and MimeLiteMVR beat lower bounds for any server-only method when δ≪Lmuch-less-than𝛿𝐿\delta\ll L.

S4.T1.footnotes: Num. clients (N𝑁N) can be same order as num. total rounds or even ∞\infty, making the bounds vacuous.Adam requires large batch-size S≥G2/ϵ𝑆superscript𝐺2italic-ϵS\geq G^{2}/\epsilon to converge [47, 70]. Convergence of FedAdam with client sampling is unknown ([46] only analyze with full client participation).Requires K≥σ2/G2𝐾superscript𝜎2superscript𝐺2K\geq\sigma^{2}/G^{2} number of local updates. Typically, intra-client variance is small (σ2≲G2less-than-or-similar-tosuperscript𝜎2superscript𝐺2\sigma^{2}\lesssim G^{2}).Requires K≥L/δ𝐾𝐿𝛿K\geq L/\delta number of local updates. Faster than the lower bound (and hence any Server-Only algorithm) when δ≪Lmuch-less-than𝛿𝐿\delta\ll L i.e. our methods can take advantage of Hessian similarity, whereas Server-Only methods cannot. In worst case, δ≈L𝛿𝐿\delta\approx L and all methods are comparable.
references: Table 1 summarizes the rates of Mime (highlighted in blue) and MimeLite (highlighted in green) and compares them to Server-Only methods when using SGD, Adam and momentum methods as the base algorithms. We will first examine the convergence of Mime and MimeLite with a generic base optimizer and show that its properties are preserved in the federated setting. We then examine a specific momentum based base optimizer, and prove that Mime and MimeLite can be asymptotically faster than the best server-only method. This is the first result to prove the usefulness of local steps and demonstrate asymptotic speed-ups.

If we take a sufficient number of local steps K≥G2/σ2𝐾superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2K\geq G^{2}/\sigma^{2}, then we have G~=𝒪​(G)~𝐺𝒪𝐺\tilde{G}=\mathcal{O}(G) in the above rates. On comparing with the rates in Table 1 for Server-Only SGD, we see that Mime exactly matches its rates. MimeLite matches the asymptotic term but has a few higher order terms. Note that when using SGD as the base optimizer, MimeLite becomes exactly the same as FedAvg and hence has the same rate of convergence.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2: Validation % accuracies after training for 1000 rounds. Best results for each dataset is underlined and the best within each base optimizer is bolded. The number of clients sampled per round has been reduced for Mime and MimeLite to ensure all methods have equal client and server communication. Final accuracies obtained by Mime and MimeLite are competitive with FedAvg, especially with adaptive base optimizers. FedAvg seems unstable with Adam.

Table 2 summarizes the results.

Note that the average number of rounds a client participates in (computed as sampled clients×\timesnumber of rounds//number of clients) provides an indication of how much of the training data is seen with Shakespeare being closest to the cross-silo setting and StackOverflow representing the most cross-device in nature.

references:
We perform 4 tasks over 3 datasets:
i) On the EMNIST62 dataset

we run a convex multi-class (62 classes) logistic regression model, and ii) a convolution model with two CNN layers and two dense layers and dropout.
iii) On the
Shakespeare
dataset, we train a single layer LSTM model with state size of 256 and embedding size of 8 to predict the next character

.
iv) Finally, on the
StackOverflow
dataset

, we train a next word prediction language model with embedding size of 96, a LSTM layer of size 670, and a vocabulary size of 1000.
In all cases we report the top-1 test accuracy in our experiments.
All datasets use the metadata indicating the original authors to separate them into multiple clients yielding naturally partitioned datasets. Table
summarizes the statistics about the different datasets. Note that the average number of rounds a client participates in (computed as sampled clients
\times
number of rounds
number of clients) provides an indication of how much of the training data is seen with
Shakespeare
being closest to the cross-silo setting and
StackOverflow
representing the most cross-device in nature.
We use Tensorflow federated datasets
to generate the datasets. Our federated learning simulation code is written in Jax
and is open-sourced at
redactedforanonymity

.
Black and white was reversed in EMNIST62 (i.e. subtracted from 1) to make them similar to MNIST.
The preprocessing for
Shakespeare
and
StackOverflow
datasets exactly matches that of

references:
Thus, SGDm can be represented in the above generic form with 𝒰​(𝒈,𝒔)=(1−β)​𝒈+β​𝒔𝒰𝒈𝒔1𝛽𝒈𝛽𝒔\mathcal{U}(\bm{g},\bm{s})=(1-\beta)\bm{g}+\beta\bm{s} and 𝒱​(𝒈,𝒔)=(1−β)​𝒈+β​𝒔𝒱𝒈𝒔1𝛽𝒈𝛽𝒔\mathcal{V}(\bm{g},\bm{s})=(1-\beta)\bm{g}+\beta\bm{s}. Table 5 in Appendix shows how other algorithms like Adam, Adagrad, etc. can be represented in this manner. We keep the update 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} to be linear in the gradient 𝒈𝒈\bm{g}, whereas 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} can be more complicated.
This implies that while the parameter update step 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} is relatively resilient to receiving a biased gradient 𝒈𝒈\bm{g} while 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} can be much more sensitive.

references: In this section we see how to use momentum based variance reduction
to reduce the variance of the updates and improve convergence. It should be noted that MVR does not exactly fit the
Mime
framework (
BaseAlg
) since it requires computing gradients at two points on the same batch. However, it is straightforward to extend the idea of
Mime
to MVR as we will now do. We use MVR as a theoretical justification for why the usual momentum works well in practice. An interesting future direction would be to adapt the algorithm and analysis of
, which does fit the framework of
Mime
For the sake of convenience, we summarize the notation used in the proof in a table.
